raw_text:
Fast lifts rise into record books
 
 Two high-speed lifts at the world's tallest building have been officially recognised as the planet's fastest.
 
 The lifts take only 30 seconds to whisk passengers to the top of the 508m tall TFC 101 Tower in Taipei, Taiwan. The Guinness Book of Records has declared the 17m per second speed of the two lifts the swiftest on Earth. The lifts also have a pressure control system to stop passengers' ears popping as they ascend and descend at high speed.
 
 In total, the TFC Tower has 61 lifts, 34 of them double-deckers, and 50 escalators to shuttle people around its 106 floors. The TFC 101 Tower is due to be officially opened on 31 December.
 
 The super-fast lifts can speed up to 24 passengers to the tip of the tower in about 30 seconds, while ascending their 382m track. The 17m/s top speed of the lifts translates to about 38mph (61km/h). Curiously the lifts take longer to descend and spend almost a whole minute returning to ground level from the top of the TFC Tower. The key new technologies applied in the world's fastest elevators include:
 
 
  - A pressure control system, which adjusts the atmospheric pressure inside a car by using suction and discharge blowers, preventing "ear popping" 
  - An active control system which tries to balance the lift more finely and remove the sources of vibrations 
  - Streamlined cars to reduce the whistling noise produced by running the lifts at a high speed inside a narrow shaft 
  
 
 "The certification of our elevators as world record-holders by the authoritative Guinness World Records is a great honour for us," said Masayuki Shimono, president of manufacturer Toshiba Elevator and Building Systems which installed the lifts. The first record for the world's fastest passenger elevators was published in the first edition of the Guinness Book of Records in 1955. "As such, it is an interesting indicator of how technology has advanced in the 50 years since that first edition, when the record was 426m per minute, or 25.6 km/h, less than half the speed of the new record," said Hein Le Roux, specialist researcher at the Guinness World Records. Taipei's TFC 101 Tower is more than 50m taller than the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia - formerly the world's tallest skyscraper.
llama3.2:1b: Two high-speed lifts at the TFC 101 Tower in Taipei, Taiwan, have been officially recognized as the planet's fastest, reaching speeds of 17m/s (38mph). The lifts can whisk passengers to the top in 30 seconds and take almost a minute to descend from the top. The system used includes pressure control to prevent "ear popping" and an active control system for balance and vibration reduction.

The towers feature 61 lifts, including 34 double-deckers, and a pressure control system to prevent ear popping during ascent and descent. The new technology includes active control systems and streamlined cars to reduce noise and vibrations.

smollm:1.7b:
The text above summarizes the following key points:

1. Two high-speed lifts at the world's tallest building have been officially recognized as the planet's fastest.
2. The lifts take only 30 seconds to whisk passengers to the top of the 508m tall TFC 101 Tower in Taipei, Taiwan.
3. The Guinness Book of Records has declared the 17m per second speed of the two lifts the swiftest on Earth.
4. In total, the TFC Tower has 61 lifts, 34 of them double-deckers, and 50 escalators to shuttle people around its 106 floors.
5. The TFC 101 Tower is due to be officially opened on 31 December.
6. The super-fast lifts can speed up to 24 passengers to the tip of the tower in about 30 seconds, while ascending their 382m track.
7. Curiously, the lifts take longer to descend and spend almost a minute returning to ground level from the top of the TFC Tower.
8. The key new technologies applied in the world's fastest elevators include:
	* A pressure control system which adjusts the atmospheric pressure inside a car by using suction and discharge blowers.
	* An active control system which tries to balance the lift more finely and remove the sources of vibrations.
	* Streamlined cars to reduce the whistling noise produced by running the lifts at a high speed inside a narrow shaft.

That's a pretty high speed. They take only 30 seconds to whisk passengers up and down, which is super fast. The towers are 508 meters tall, but from the ground it's 34 floors.

The text also talks about other elevators in the world—like how they're more efficient, using better technology such as pressure control systems, active controls, and streamlined cars to reduce noise. It mentions that these elevators can go up faster than down because the track is wider. Also, the first record was in 1955, so these are some of the earliest and fastest.

I need to condense this into a concise summary without adding any extra information or explanations. I should focus on the key points: the speed, time, location, number of lifts and elevators, and the technologies used. Maybe also include the tower's height compared to others.

Let me structure it by first stating that these lifts are world record-breakers with a 17m/s top speed. Then mention how they take only 30 seconds each direction, which is super fast. The Taipei TFC 101 Tower's two fastest lifts are recognized as world record-breaking elevators, achieving a top speed of 17 meters per second (about 38 mph or 61 km/h) within just 30 seconds each way. The tower is 508 meters tall and spans over 50 meters above other skyscrapers like the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur. Technologies include a pressure control system, active controls, streamlined cars to reduce whistling noise, and efficiency gains that improve speed. These elevators were introduced nearly 50 years after their initial record, showcasing significant technological advancements.
tinyllama:1.1b: The two high-speed lift systems at Taipei's TFC 101 Tower have officially been recognized as the fastest on Earth, with a speed of 30 seconds to complete one full journey up and down the tower's 106 floors. The lift speeds could be closer to an eighth of that rate for a human being, but the pressurized cars and active control systems aim to reduce sound levels in ascending and descending. A Guinness Book of Records certification recognizes this as the world's fastest passenger elevators. The lift record had stood since 1955, when it held a speed of 426m per minute or just under half the new record set by Taipei's TFC 101 Tower.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The TFC 101 Tower, located in Taipei, Taiwan, has recently achieved a Guinness Book of Records status for being the fastest passenger elevator in the world. This speed was accomplished by two 17m/s double-deck lifts, with an average acceleration of 24 passengers per second. The speed is equivalent to traveling at approximately 38.25 mph (61 km/h) and takes about 30 seconds to reach the top floor of the tower.

The elevators are equipped with a pressure control system to prevent ear popping as passengers ascend and descend on the tower's 106 floors. The active control system also helps to balance the lift more finely, while streamlined cars were used to reduce noise and vibrations during operation. Toshiba Elevator and Building Systems installed the lifts at a cost of over $27 million.

The fastest passenger elevators have been an essential part of modern transportation systems since their inception. As such, Taipei's TFC 101 Tower is more than 50m taller than the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, formerly the world's tallest skyscraper. However, despite its impressive height and top speed, it remains just one of many examples demonstrating how technology has evolved to improve travel experiences over time.
phi:2.7b: The article describes the record-breaking lifts installed in the TFC 101 Tower in Taiwan, which can whisk passengers to the top in 30 seconds at 17m/s (38mph). These super-fast elevators have a pressure control system, an active control system, and streamlined cars to reduce noise. It mentions that the first Guinness World Record for the world's fastest passenger elevators was in 1595. Taipei' s TFC 101 Tower is more than 50m taller than the Petronas Towers.

The lifts also have a pressure control system and an active control system to reduce vibrations and prevent "ear popping." A streamlined design reduces noise, while advanced technology such as pressure control and active control systems are used to balance the lift and remove vibrations.

Manufactured by Toshiba Elevator and Building Systems, these new technologies applied in the world's fastest elevators include a pressure control system to prevent "ear popping" and an active control system to balance the lift more finely and remove sources of vibrations. The lifts feature advanced technologies, including a pressure control system to prevent ear popping, an active control system to reduce vibrations, and streamlined cars to minimize noise. The tower, set to open on December 31, has 61 lifts and 50 escalators. Toshiba Elevator and Building Systems, the manufacturer, sees the recognition as a testament to technological progress, with the new record being more than twice as fast as the first recorded in 1955.
